title: A Malibu Barbie Café pop-up is coming to Boston
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: The Malibu Barbie Café pop-up opens April 17 at 101 S. Market St., near Faneuil Hall in Boston.
The dining experience features a 1970s Malibu beach theme and a menu by 'MasterChef' finalist Chef Becky Brown.
Tickets cost $25, providing credit for food and merchandise, available exclusively through Bucket Listers with a waitlist open.

title: Baystate Health will no longer prescribe hormones to trans youth
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Baystate Health will stop prescribing hormones to transgender youth under 18 due to Medicaid and Medicare funding threats.
The Springfield-based center will transfer patients' medications to Transhealth or other chosen providers but continue mental health services.
Fenway Health and New Hampshire have also changed policies on gender-affirming care amid increasing federal and state restrictions.

title: Gloucester struggles for answers as search for sunken fishing boat continues
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: The fishing boat Lily Jean sank off Gloucester with seven aboard; all are presumed dead.
Authorities are using sonar technology to locate the sunken vessel and investigate the cause of the sinking.
Gov. Maura Healey and state officials express condolences, highlighting the community's grief and support efforts.

title: A new hotel has been approved in Boston’s Seaport
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: A 15-story hotel with 438 rooms has been approved in Boston's Seaport District on Anchor Street.
The project by DGH Hotel Partners will include an indoor/outdoor lobby bar and a rooftop space.
The hotel is part of a campus near the Convention Center, aiming for LEED Gold sustainable design.

title: $22m Beacon Hill townhome sale sets Boston’s single-family home sale record
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: A Beacon Hill townhome at 46 Chestnut St. sold for $22 million, setting a Boston single-family home sale record.
Seller Crest City Capital renovated the 9,000-square-foot, four-story home over two years, preserving historic Greek Revival details.
The restored residence includes modern amenities like a 15-foot ceiling garage, terraced roof decks, and a double-height living space.

title: Dave Epstein on the possibilities of more snow Friday, a coastal storm Sunday-Monday
author: David Epstein
bullets: Massachusetts, including Boston, expected to see 2-4 inches of snow from Friday's minor storm.
Potential coastal storm Sunday night into Monday could bring snow depending on its track.
Astronomical tides early next week may cause minor coastal flooding and beach erosion.

title: Why a Virginia mom is running the 2026 Boston Marathon: ‘Stories can save lives’
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Elizabeth Ayres from Henrico, Virginia, will run the 2026 Boston Marathon in support of suicide prevention.
Motivated by her mother's suicide, Ayres uses running as a tool for healing and raising mental health awareness.
Ayres partners with the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention to encourage open discussions on mental health.

title: Report: Bill Russell’s widow sues his daughter over breach of contract
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Jeannine Russell filed a lawsuit against Karen Russell, alleging comments tarnished Bill Russell's legacy.
The lawsuit claims Karen Russell violated a 2015 confidentiality and nondisparagement agreement with Jeannine.
Karen previously challenged Bill Russell's competency in 2015; dispute settled with a financial agreement.

title: Pavel Zacha’s Olympic dream turned into a nightmare due to ill-timed injury
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Pavel Zacha missed the Olympics due to an upper-body injury sustained on January 29 during a game against the Flyers.
The decision for Zacha to skip the Olympics was mutual with the Bruins and Czech National Team due to his slow recovery.
Zacha has resumed non-contact practice; Boston Bruins aim for his return by their next game on February 27 against Columbus.

title: Trump admin responds to lawsuit from Healey aide over work authorization
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Valentina Amaro Bowser, Venezuelan immigrant and Healey's media director, sues Trump administration over visa application hold affecting job status.
Trump administration argues Massachusetts federal court lacks jurisdiction and national security concerns outweigh Bowser's job loss risk.
USCIS application hold for Venezuelans blocks Bowser's residency approval, placing her on unpaid leave after H-1B visa expiry.
